entries: {@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, {@item Divination Focus|DDFateWeaver}, {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Shortsword|XPHB}, {@item Explorer's Pack|XPHB}, and 22 GP; or (B) 50 GP

Fate Weavers can bend and warp the threads that bind all of reality together, granting them the power to change the destiny of themselves and everyone around them. These threads, the so-called {@i 'threads of fate'}, form the underlying structure of the multiverse. Some represent creatures, places, or objects and tell the stories of their journeys through reality, while others represent the bonds between those things. They intertwine and influence each other’s paths as time marches from future to present to past.

The past is a tightly woven tapestry—an impossibly intricate ledger of {@i everything} that has ever happened. The future is a web of possibility—a forest of branching threads that represent every possible outcome simultaneously. The present is where a Fate Weaver does their work: tugging at the threads to favor branches that realize their desires and avoid those that spell doom.

Fate Weavers are incredibly rare, and they can come about in many ways. Some are simply gifted from birth, some become connected to the threads through a profound act of magic, and others still are granted knowledge through contact with a being of immense power. Whatever their origin, most Fate Weavers find that dodging the call to adventure is futile. After all, it’s hard to avoid destiny when you’re the one pulling the strings.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By manipulating the threads of fate, you can cast spells. See chapter 7 for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules with Fate Weaver spells, which appear in the {@filter Fate Weaver spell list|spells|class=Fate Weaver (FW:R)} later in the class's description.

entries.name: Cantrips.
entries: You know three Fate Weaver cantrips of your choice. {@spell Guidance}, {@spell Prestidigitation}, and {@spell Sacred Flame} are recommended. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can replace one of your cantrips from this feature with another Fate Weaver cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Fate Weaver levels 4 and 10, you learn another Fate Weaver cantrip of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Fate Weaver Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots.
entries: The Fate Weaver Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+.
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 Fate Weaver spells. {@spell Guiding Bolt}, {@spell Healing Word}, {@spell Mage Armor}, and {@spell Shield} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Fate Weaver levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Fate Weaver Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Fate Weaver spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Fate Weaver Features table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Fate Weaver, your list of prepared spells can include six Fate Weaver spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

If another Fate Weaver feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Fate Weaver spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells.
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing any of the spells there with other Fate Weaver spells for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability.
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Fate Weaver spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus.
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus|XPHB} or a {@item Divination Focus|DDFateWeaver} as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Fate Weaver spells.

classFeature.name: Fate Weaving
entries: You have learned how to pull at the threads that underlie reality to nudge situations toward your desired outcome. You have a pool of two d6s called Fate Dice that you can spend to bend fate. Immediately after a creature you can see within 30 feet of you rolls the d20 for a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to expend 1 Fate Die and roll it, then apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to the d20 roll.
Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a Long Rest.
The pool's maximum number of dice increases when you reach certain levels, as shown in the Fate Dice column of the Fate Weaver Features table.

classFeature.name: Boon of Fate
entries: Your mere existence in the world makes reality malleable, and with your guidance, others around you can bend their own fate. As a Magic action, you can expend 1 Fate Die to give a Boon of Fate to a creature within 5 feet of yourself. A creature can have only one Boon of Fate at a time.
Once within the next hour when the creature fails a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, the creature can dismiss the Boon of Fate to reroll the test, potentially turning the failure into a success.

classFeature.name: Spell Weaving
entries: The weave of magic itself is a construct made from the same threads you tinker with. Your ability to rearrange these threads affords you a great flexibility in casting your spells. You can affect your spell slots using the options below.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots.
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} you can expend two spell slots of the same level to create one slot of the next level up. For example, you can expend two first level spell slots to create a second level slot. The created spell slots vanish at the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Recovering Spell Slots.
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can expend one spell slot of level 2+ to recover two expended slots of a lower level. The sum of the recovered spell slot levels must be equal to or less than the level of the slot expended. For example, you can expend one third level slot to recover one first and one second level slot.

classFeature.name: Fate Weaver Subclass
entries: You gain a Fate Weaver subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Fate Weaver levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Fate Weaver level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XPHB} feat or another {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Premonition
entries: When you roll Initiative, you can regain a number of expended Fate Dice equal to half your maximum number of Fate Dice (rounded down). Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Pattern Shift
entries: By subtly rearranging the threads you hold, you can adapt to unanticipated situations. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can replace one of the level 1+ Fate Weaver spells you have prepared for your Spellcasting feature with another level 1+ spell from the {@filter Fate Weaver spell list.|spells|class=Fate Weaver (FW:R)}

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XPHB} feat or another {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XPHB} feat or another {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XPHB} feat or another {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Straight from the Source
entries: Your power comes not from a divinity, nor the primal spirits of the world, nor a well of arcana, but from the fundamental reality that allows those things to exist in the first place. Whenever you change your list of prepared spells, you can choose two of your prepared spells from the {@filter Cleric|spells|class=Cleric}, {@filter Druid|spells|class=Druid}, or {@filter Wizard|spells|class=Wizard} spell lists.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Fate Weaver subclass.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@filter Epic Boon feat|feats|category=EB} or another {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice for which you qualify. {@feat Boon of Truesight|XPHB} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Threadspinner
entries: By pulling part of your own thread into the material plane, you can drag part of the web with it and manipulate the threads near you with ease. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can enter a state of heightened power and gain the benefits below for 10 minutes. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 7+ spell slot (no action required).

entries.name: Alter Reality.
entries: You have the {@spell Wish} spell prepared, and if you cast {@spell Wish}, you can choose the Roll Redo option without suffering any of the stress it would normally cause.
If you choose an option that does cause you to suffer the stress, there is a only a 10 percent chance that you are unable to cast {@spell Wish} ever again, instead of 33 percent.

entries.name: Held Aloft.
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}, and you can hover. As you fly, the threads of fate become visible in the air around you.

entries.name: Warp and Weft.
entries: Whenever you use a feature that expends Fate Dice, you expend one less die. Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Oracle
entries: {@i Peer Into the Web of Fate}

All Fate Weavers can see the paths laid by the threads, but only you can {@i truly} read them. You have learned how to tease secrets from the tangled branches of the web of fate and apply that knowledge to the present. This foresight is not infinite, for the web is unfathomably complex, but you can see just far enough to know what is possible. Whatever destiny awaits you and your companions, you are likely to see it coming.

subclassFeature.name: Oracle Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in the Oracle Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Oracle Spells
rows: {@spell Detect Magic}, {@spell Identify}, {@spell Augury}, {@spell See Invisibility}

subclassFeature.name: Soothsayer
entries: Your view into to the web of fate allows you to effortlessly channel spells that reveal its secrets. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Guiding Hand.
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. When you cast {@spell Guidance}, its range is 30 feet instead of Touch.

entries.name: Minimal Exertion.
entries: When you cast a level 1+ spell from the Divination school that has a casting time of an action, you can instead cast it as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: Self-Sufficient.
entries: When you cast a spell from the Divination school, you can do so without any Verbal components, and you can replace any Material components that are consumed by the spell or that have a cost specified in the spell with a {@item Divination Focus|DDFateWeaver}, which is not consumed.

subclassFeature.name: Shared Insight
entries: You can share a small fraction of your view into the future with those touched by your magic. Whenever a creature uses your Boon of Fate to reroll a failed {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, they gain a bonus to the roll equal to your {@table Proficiency Bonus|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Seer's Stitchwork
entries: Because you can read their patterns, you have learned to guide the threads more precisely. Whenever you use Fate Weaving, you can roll the Fate Die twice and apply the higher roll as the bonus or penalty.

subclassFeature.name: Precognitive Reflex
entries: Your awareness of the future is so finely tuned that you can respond to events before they even happen. Once per turn, if you've already taken your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can expend 1 Fate Die to take an additional {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}. You can only take one {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} per triggering effect.

subclassFeature.name: Paragon of Prophecy
entries: Your view of the web of fate is unparalleled by any other mortal. You always have the {@spell Foresight} spell prepared, and you can cast it by expending 7 Fate Dice. Whenever you cast {@spell Foresight}, you can choose to change its casting time to one Action instead of one minute. If you do so, its duration is only ten minutes. The Minimal Exertion benefit of your Soothsayer feature does not affect this casting of the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Void
entries: {@i Become Unbound by Natural Laws}

The threads of fate don't exist in the material world, they wind though an endless void where distance is meaningless and time flows in all directions. Beings beyond comprehension call this nothingness home, and your connection to the threads has changed you to be more like them; unburdened by the laws that govern mundane reality. You can slip through the gaps to tug at the stitches holding everything together, though you must be careful which threads you pull, lest you unravel yourself completely.

subclassFeature.name: Void Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in Void Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Void Spells
rows: {@spell False Life}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers}, {@spell Darkness}, {@spell Misty Step}

subclassFeature.name: Void Level 3
entries: Your bond to the endless space between the threads causes strange interactions with the world around you. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Exposed to Vacuum.
entries: You know the {@spell Frostbite|XGE} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. When you cast {@spell Frostbite|XGE}, the target takes additional Cold damage equal to your {@table Proficiency Bonus|XPHB}, even on a successful save.

entries.name: Null Pointer.
entries: Your creature type is Undefined, meaning you are not affected by any spells or other abilities that only target certain types of creatures.

entries.name: Tapping Infinity.
entries: Whenever you cast a level 2+ spell listed on the Void Spells table, you regain one expended spell slot. The slot you regain must be of a level lower than the slot you expended.

subclassFeature.name: Void Level 6
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Void Level 10
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Void Level 14
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Void Level 18
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Phoenix
entries: {@i Burn with Eternal Flame}

Your power draws from the immortal flame that fuels the legendary phoenix. You or your ancestors perhaps rendered a phoenix a great service, or you were born in its presence. Whatever the cause, a shard of the phoenix's power dwells within you.

That power is a mixed blessing. Like the mythical creature, you can invoke fiery energy and gain the ability to cheat death itself. This power comes at a cost. The fire within you seethes, demanding to be unleashed. You sometimes find yourself absentmindedly feeding fires. You can't bear to allow a fire to sputter out. You feel most comfortable while holding a lit torch or sitting in front of a campfire.

More importantly, this gift comes with no special protection from fire. You are as vulnerable as any other creature to fiery magic, including your own. Those of this aspect can use their powers to pull themselves back from the brink of death, and all too often their own rash nature or reliance on destructive magic is what puts them there in the first place.
NEW TEXT

You can see threads beginning and ending all around you, but yours is different. An immortal flame burns inside you, carrying your thread Your thread has become linked to that of the legendary phoenix,
Oracle text

All Fate Weavers can see the paths laid by the threads, but only you can {@i truly} read them. You have learned how to tease secrets from the tangled branches of the web of fate and apply that knowledge to the present. This foresight is not infinite, for the web is unfathomably complex, but you can see just far enough to know what is possible. Whatever destiny awaits you and your companions, you are likely to see it coming.

subclassFeature.name: Phoenix Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in the Phoenix Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Phoenix Spells
rows: {@spell Burning Hands}, {@spell Hellish Rebuke}, {@spell Heat Metal}, {@spell Scorching Ray}

subclassFeature.name: Phoenix Level 3
entries: You gain the benefits below.

entries.name: Hot to the Touch.
entries: Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack roll, the attacker takes Fire damage equal to your {@table Proficiency Bonus|XPHB}.

entries.name: WIP.
entries: Spells you cast ignore Resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: WIP.
entries: You know the {@spell Produce Flame} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. When you cast {@spell Produce Flame}, its range is 30 feet instead of Touch.

subclassFeature.name: Blazing Mantle
entries: As a bonus action by spending a fate die, you magically wreathe yourself in swirling fire, as your eyes glow like hot coals. For 1 minute you gain the following benefits and you can spend another fate die as a bonus action to prolong your Mantle of the Phoenix for an additional minute:

entries.name: WIP.
entries: Your body is wreathed in swirling ethereal flame. You shed {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 30-foot radius and {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} for an additional 30 feet.

entries.name: WIP.
entries: WIP.

entries.name: WIP.
entries: Whenever you roll Fire damage on your turn, the roll gains a bonus equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Flames of Rebirth
entries: The energy within you grows restless and vengeful. In the face of defeat, it surges outward to preserve you in a fiery roar.

If you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to draw on the immortal flames of the phoenix. You are instead reduced to 1 hit point, and each creature within 10 feet of you takes fire damage equal to four rolls of your fate dice.
If you use this feature while under the effects of your Blazing Mantle, this feature gains a bonus to its fire damage equal to your fate weaver level.
You can use this feature once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest or if you spend a use of your Spell Weaving feature to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Phoenix Level 14
entries: You learn the fire storm and investiture of flame spells and they do not count against your total number of prepared spells. When you cast either of these spells, you instantly enter your Blazing Mantle (no action required) and without spending a fate die.

subclassFeature.name: Phoenix Level 18
entries: You finally master the spark of fire that dances within you. While under the effect of your Mantle of Phoenix feature, you gain additional benefits:

Fiery wings sprout out from your back, granting you the ability to magically fly. You have a flying speed of 60 feet and can hover. Movement from this magical flight does not provoke opportunity attacks.
Once per turn whenever you cast a spell that deals fire damage, you can choose to ignore resistances and immunity to fire damage for that spell until the end of the current turn.

Your body becomes more akin to the fiery elemental your powers are drawn from. You can occupy a creature's space and vice versa. Whenever a creature starts its turn whilst occupying your space, it takes 2d6 fire damage.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Keeper
entries: {@i Bear the Burden of Cruel Fates}

Though you have some control over the threads, sometimes a small nudge is not enough. To ensure that those around you are safe, you  is to take their pain upon yourself. You can shield others from the cruelty that destiny so often delivers, or bear it yourself if need be.

subclassFeature.name: Keeper Spells
entries: When you reach a Fate Weaver level specified in the Keeper Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Keeper Spells
rows: {@spell Sanctuary}, {@spell Shield of Faith}, {@spell Warding Bond}, {@spell Web}
{@spell Circle of Power}, {@spell Wall of Force}

subclassFeature.name: Bulwark
entries: When your companions are in danger, you are always prepared to take the hit. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Armored.
entries: You gain training with Light armor, Medium armor, and Shields. Additionally, you can use a Shield as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Fate Weaver spells.

entries.name: Ready Defense.
entries: You know the {@spell Resistance} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of Fate Weaver cantrips. If you cast it on yourself, you can do so as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} and it does not require {@variantrule Concentration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Guardian.
entries: You gain either the {@feat Protection} or {@feat Interception} Fighting Style feat, your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Keeper Level 6
entries: When a creature within 30 feet of you is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you can expend 1 Fate Die to cause them to drop to 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} instead.

subclassFeature.name: Keeper Level 10
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Keeper Level 14
entries: WIP.

subclassFeature.name: Keeper Level 18
entries: WIP.

item.name: Divination Focus
entries: A Divination Focus is an item or set of items used to glean hints about the future. A Fate Weaver can use such an item as a Spellcasting Focus. Below are a list of some common types of {@i Divination Focuses} and their method of use, but many other items and methods exist across many cultures.

items: A deck of illustrated cards which are shuffled and dealt.
A set of coins which are flipped and matched to patterns in a book.
Various bones, shells, dice, and other trinkets which are cast onto a surface.
A bowl in which items are burnt and patterns are read in the flames.

entries: You can consult a Divination Focus by performing a ritual over the course of 1 minute. During the ritual, you ask a single question about yourself or another creature concerning an event to occur in the near future. By reading the patterns in the Divination Focus, you receive an omen from the DM hinting toward some aspect of the event. These omens are typically vague and unclear, and it is up to you to interpret their meaning.
For example, you may ask {@i "What awaits us at my companion's reunion with their estranged family?"}, and the DM might reply, {@i "The card you draw represents tension and unease."}

spell.name: Dewthorne's Defer Destiny

time.condition: which you take when a creature you can see within range makes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}

components.m: a sealed glass ampule with a needle and thread inside

entries: You pull the threads of fate away from one creature and hold them, preparing to re-thread them around another creature at a later time.
Record the number rolled by the triggering creature. The triggering creature must then reroll the {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} and use the new roll.

At any point while you maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}, you can choose a creature you can see within range (you can choose yourself) that is about to make a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. Instead of rolling, the creature uses the number previously recorded and the spell ends.
If the spell ends before you select a second target, you take {@damage 4d6} Force damage as the threads of fate tear away from your grasp.
